timeline.message: Send Workspace Creator information to RDR

timeline.bodyText: Please make a new MapStruct mapper for this. There's a guide and tutorial in the top level README.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: nit: Usually I'd use @Mock for mocking value objects (and @MockBean for beans). There may be a reason not to do so here.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: I would have expected the creator to be a field passed in to buildDbWorkspace.
timeline.author: jaycarlton
jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: Is there anything else you can verify?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: If you're using a real DAO, then you should be able to fetch the saved object and compare fields.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: i actually do not need to verify this, the purpose of this test is to ensure the creator information is different
replies.author: NehaBroad

replies.bodyText:
and i am verifying the RdrWorkspace converted object attribute value is matched via
verify(mockRdrApi).exportWorkspaces(Arrays.asList(rdrWorkspace));
replies.author: NehaBroad

timeline.bodyText: With fluent constructsors or builders, please break before every new parameter.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
so spotlessApply is putting them in one line. i had it like ....
.userId(2l)
.familyName("email")
.givenName("icannothas"));
replies.author: NehaBroad

replies.bodyText: ok. Spotless isn't the best poet.
replies.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: Yay! look how small it is!
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: This is great, but even better would be to have the fields named the same way.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: It's better if we can order them by source, target, and then use a string utility to alphabetize them.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: We've already got different names for the db and model classes here, and now the RDR model is yet another mapping. This is just way more complicated than it needs to be. But the mapper sweeps it all under the rug in a really nice way.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: For anything you need to ignore, please put a comment indicating why it's required/safe/desired.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText:
nit: you can get around all ternary operators if you just set all the flages to unset first, then iterate over the enums and use a mapping function, sort of like the PropertyMapper class. Probably too fancy to bother with, but it's a neat trick.
So it'd be like AccessToCare.setRdrFlag(rdrDemogrphic); You can just zip down the set and call the setRdrFlag() method on each one for the thing and avoid all the branching.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: You may want to find out when this returns null. Maybe a unit test there. In general, if you have to do a filter on non-null, there might be a constraint you could add upstream so this doesn't happen. Not always though.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.message: PR comments: Add comment and sort out mapping attribute
